name: std::path::Path::normalize_lexically
doc:
Normalize a path, including `..` without traversing the filesystem. Returns an error if normalization would leave leading `..` components.
This function always resolves `..` to the "lexical" parent. That is "a/b/../c" will always resolve to `a/c` which can change the meaning of the path. In particular, `a/c` and `a/b/../c` are distinct on many systems because `b` may be a symbolic link, so its parent isn't `a`.
[`path::absolute`](absolute) is an alternative that preserves `..`. Or [`Path::canonicalize`] can be used to resolve any `..` by querying the filesystem.
